title: How to Write Action Titles Like McKinsey: A Complete Guide
excerpt: Learn the secret behind McKinsey's powerful action titles. Discover the formula that makes consulting slides instantly more persuasive and actionable.
content:
Action titles are the single most important element of any consulting slide. They're not just labels—they're the main message of your slide, condensed into a single, powerful sentence. McKinsey consultants spend more time crafting their action titles than on any other slide element, and for good reason.

What Are Action Titles?

An action title is a slide title that tells the reader what to think or do. Unlike descriptive titles (which merely label the slide content), action titles make a specific claim, present a conclusion, or recommend an action.

Descriptive title: "Q3 Sales Performance"
Action title: "Q3 sales exceeded target by 12% driven by enterprise segment growth"

The difference is stark. The descriptive title tells you what's on the slide. The action title tells you why the slide matters.

The Action Title Formula

McKinsey action titles follow a simple but powerful formula:

[Observation/Result] + [Key Driver/Reason] + [Supporting Context]

Let's break this down:

1. Start with the So-What

Your first few words should state the most important finding, conclusion, or recommendation. This is the "so what"—the insight that matters most to your audience.

Example: "Customer churn reduced by 23%..."

2. Add the Key Driver

Immediately follow with the primary reason or cause behind your main finding. This adds credibility and context.

Example: "...due to implementation of proactive retention campaigns..."

3. Provide Supporting Context

Include additional details that strengthen your claim—timeframes, segments, or comparisons.

Example: "...surpassing the industry benchmark of 15% over the same period."

Common Action Title Mistakes

Even experienced consultants struggle with action titles. Here are the most common pitfalls:

1. Being Too Vague

Weak: "Market Analysis Overview"
Strong: "Market growth of 8% CAGR creates $2B opportunity in premium segment"

2. Including Multiple Thoughts

Stick to one main message per slide. If you have multiple insights, create multiple slides.

3. Making It Too Long

Aim for 12-15 words maximum. If your title wraps to three lines, it's too long.

4. Using Jargon

Write for your audience, not for yourself. Avoid industry acronyms unless you're certain everyone knows them.

The "So What" Test

Before finalizing any action title, ask yourself: "So what?"

If you can't answer why your audience should care, your title isn't strong enough. Every action title should pass this test—it should clearly communicate why the slide matters to the decision-makers in the room.

Examples by Slide Type

Executive Summary Slides

  • "Three initiatives will reduce costs by $50M annually while improving service quality"
  • "Market entry strategy projects $120M revenue potential with 18-month payback period"

Data/Chart Slides

  • "Revenue growth accelerated to 15% YoY, outpacing market average by 4 percentage points"
  • "Customer acquisition cost decreased 30% following implementation of referral program"

Process/Workflow Slides

  • "Streamlined approval process reduces cycle time from 14 days to 3 days"
  • "Automation of routine tasks frees 40% of team capacity for strategic work"

Practice Exercise

Transform these descriptive titles into action titles:

  1. "Competitive Landscape" → "Competitor X's pricing strategy creates opportunity for 10% market share gain"
  2. "Employee Survey Results" → "78% of employees cite career development as top priority, driving 25% higher engagement scores"
  3. "Financial Projections" → "EBITDA margin to expand from 12% to 18% by 2026 driven by operational improvements"

Conclusion

Mastering action titles is one of the highest-ROI skills you can develop as a consultant or business professional. They force clarity of thought, respect your audience's time, and dramatically improve the persuasiveness of your presentations.

Remember: every slide is an argument. Your action title is your thesis statement. Make it count.
